sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Baseline screening for presence of virus with NS3 Q80K polymorphism strongly recommended prior to initiating treatment with simeprevir in combination with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin; if present, consider alternative therapy. Screening may also be considered when used in combination with sofosbuvir.
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1, in combination with other hepatitis C antivirals: Combination therapy with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin, 150 mg ORALLY once daily for 12 weeks plus peginterferon alfa and ribavirin for an additional 12 weeks for treatment-naive patients or patients with prior relapse; continue peginterferon alfa and ribavirin for an additional 36 weeks for patients with prior treatment failure; continued treatment with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin is based on clinical response; discontinue 3-drug regimen at treatment week 4 if viral RNA levels are 25 international units/mL or greater; discontinue peginterferon alfa/ribavirin therapy at week 12 or 24 if viral RNA levels are 25 international units/mL or greater
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1, in combination with other hepatitis C antivirals: Combination therapy with sofosbuvir, 150 mg ORALLY once daily for 12 weeks in patients without cirrhosis or 24 weeks in patients with cirrhosis, regardless of previous interferon-based therapy

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• To prevent treatment failure, dosage reduction or interruption of simeprevir is not recommended.
  • If concomitant antiviral therapy is discontinued, simeprevir must be discontinued.
  • Renal impairment: No adjustment required in mild, moderate, or severe impairment
  • Hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh class A): No adjustment required
  • Hepatic impairment, moderate or severe (Child-Pugh class B or C): Use not recommended; when used concomitantly with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin, use is contraindicated in decompensated cirrhosis (moderate or severe hepatic impairment).
  • Geriatric: No adjustment required.
  • Dialysis: Unlikely to result in significant removal of simeprevir
  • East Asian ancestry: No recommendations available

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1, in combination with other hepatitis C antivirals

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Symptomatic bradycardia has been reported when amiodarone is used concomitantly with sofosbuvir in combination with other direct acting antivirals, including simeprevir; some cases have required pacemaker intervention and one case involved fatal cardiac arrest; this risk is increased with underlying cardiac comorbidities, advanced liver disease, and concomitant beta blocker use; monitoring recommended; discontinuation may be required
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- Photosensitivity reactions, including those resulting in hospitalization, have been reported with use in combination with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin; discontinuation may be necessary and monitor until resolution
  • -- Rash, sometimes severe, has been reported with use in combination with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin; monitor mild to moderate rash for progression, discontinue use if severe rash occurs, and monitor until resolution
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Hepatic decompensation and failure has been reported, mostly in patients with current advanced or decompensated cirrhosis; monitoring recommended
  • -- Moderate or severe hepatic impairment; not recommended
  • -- Bilirubin level increases, not impacting hepatic function, have been reported; monitoring recommended; discontinue if accompanied by liver transaminase increases or signs or symptoms of hepatic decompensation
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Sulfa allergy; contains sulfonamide moiety
  • Other:
  • -- Do not use as monotherapy
  • -- Increased risk of adverse reactions (eg, rash and photosensitivity) has been reported in patients with East Asian ancestry
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Combination therapy with amiodarone and sofosbuvir is not recommended
  • -- Use with moderate or strong CYP3A inducers or inhibitors not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus (With sofosbuvir, 11%; with peginterferon alfa and riboflavin, 22%), Rash (With sofosbuvir, 11%; with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin, 28%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (21% to 22%)
  • Hepatic:Hyperbilirubinemia (Grade 1, 27%; grade 2, 18%; grade 3, 4%; grade 4, less than 1%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (21%), Insomnia (14%)
  • Other:Fatigue (25%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Photosensitivity (5% to 7%), Rash (Grade 3, 1%)
  • Hepatic:Liver failure

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Simeprevir inhibits hepatitis C virus (HCV) NS3/4A protease thus interfering with viral replication. In biochemical assays, the proteolytic activity of recombinant genotype 1a and 1b HCV NS3/4A proteases were inhibited.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 4 to 6 hours
  • Effect of food: AUC increased by 61% and absorption delayed by 1 hour (high-fat, high-caloric meal); AUC increased by 69% and absorption delayed by 1.5 hours (normal-caloric meal)

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono: Protein binding: greater than 99.9%, primarily to albumin

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic: via CYP3A
  • substrate and mild inhibitor of CYP3A4: mildly inhibits intestinal CYP3A4 activity but does not affect hepatic CYP3A4 activity
  • substrate and inhibitor of P-glycoprotein
  • substrate and inhibitor of OATP1B1/3

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono: 10 to 13 hours (subjects without hepatitis C virus [HCV] infection); 41 hours (subjects with HCV infection)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • Do not interrupt dosing schedule or reduce dose
  • Swallow whole
  • Take with food
  • Give concomitantly with other antiviral drugs; if any other antiviral drug is discontinued for any reason, simeprevir must also be discontinued

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA assay; as clinically indicated and at weeks 4, 12, and 24; use a sensitive assay which has a lower limit of HCV RNA quantification of at least 25 international units/mL
  • NS3 Q80K polymorphism screening, in patients with HCV genotype 1a infection; prior to initiating therapy
  • Liver chemistry tests; before and during therapy, especially in patients who develop a bilirubin level of greater than 2.5 times ULN

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Encourage female patients of childbearing potential to avoid becoming pregnant and to use adequate contraception during treatment.
  • Advise patient to use sunscreen, wear protective clothing, and avoid sunlight or sunlamps as drug causes photosensitivity.
  • Tell patient to take appropriate precautions to prevent transmission of hepatitis C infection as effect of drug on transmission is unknown.
  • Side effects may include pruritus, nausea, myalgia, headache, and fatigue.
  • Counsel patient to immediately report a rash.
  • Tell patient to take drug with food to enhance absorption.
  • Instruct patient to swallow capsules whole.
  • Advise patient that there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
  • Instruct patient to take a missed dose as soon as possible, but if next dose is in less than 12 hours, skip the missed dose.
